title.value: OptEmbed: Learning Optimal Embedding Table for Click-through Rate Prediction
title.justification: The title is explicitly stated at the top of the paper.
title.quote: OptEmbed: Learning Optimal Embedding Table for Click-through Rate Prediction

extractions.description: The paper presents OptEmbed, a framework designed to learn an optimal embedding table for click-through rate (CTR) prediction models. The framework addresses memory usage and performance challenges in CTR models by proposing a method that prunes redundant embeddings and assigns embedding dimensions based on feature importance. OptEmbed integrates neural architecture search to optimize embedding dimensions, leading to efficient model performance. Experiments on public datasets demonstrate its effectiveness in improving model performance and reducing size.

type.justification: The paper includes experiments conducted on public datasets to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed framework, indicating that it is empirical in nature.
type.quote: Experiments on public datasets show that OptEmbed can learn a compact embedding table which can further improve the model performance.

name.justification: The paper focuses on CTR prediction, which is a core component of Recommender Systems.
name.quote: Click-through rate (CTR) prediction has been a critical task in real-world commercial recommender systems and online advertising systems.

name.justification: The paper utilizes neural architecture search techniques to optimize the embedding dimensions as part of the proposed framework.
name.quote: We propose an optimal embedding table learning framework OptEmbed, which provides a practical and general method to find an optimal embedding table for various base CTR models.

name.justification: The paper discusses CTR prediction which is directly related to online advertising systems.
name.quote: Click-through rate (CTR) prediction has been a critical task in real-world commercial recommender systems and online advertising systems.

name.justification: FNN is a base model for which experiments were conducted in the paper.

is_contributed.justification: FNN is used as a base model for demonstrating the framework's effectiveness but is not a contribution of the paper itself.
is_contributed.quote: Here we set the base model as FNN.

is_executed.justification: FNN was executed as part of experiments for evaluating the proposed OptEmbed framework.

is_compared.justification: FNN was used in experiments that compared models using OptEmbed against other methods.
